gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Texas Hold'em is simple: Make the best five-card hand using any combination of the two private hole cards dealt to you and the five community cards that are shared by all players.Texas Hold'em is a community card game, meaning that everyone shares the same set of community cards, but each player also has their own unique hole cards. The player with the best five-card hand (based on poker hand rankings) wins the pot.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Texas Hold'em can be played with 2 to 10 players.
52 cards are used (no jokers or wild cards).

In Texas Hold'em, there are two forced bets: the small blind and the big blind. These bets are made before the cards are even dealt and are designed to create action.Small Blind: The player to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually half of the big blind).Big Blind: The player two seats to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually the standard betting amount).These forced bets ensure that there's always something to play for, even before players start betting.

The dealer button rotates clockwise around the table after each hand. This determines which player is the dealer for that hand, as well as who posts the blinds. In casino play, the dealer is usually a non-playing staff member, but in home games, the button moves to each player.

Dealing in texas hold'em happends  pre-flop meaining before any comunity cards are dealt The dealer shuffles the deck and deals two hole cards face down to each player.Players can look at their own hole cards but should keep them hidden from others.The player to the left of the big blind starts the first betting round (pre-flop).

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are four betting rounds in Texas Hold'em: Pre-flop, Post-flop, Post-turn, and Post-river. Let's break down each one.

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: After everyone receives their two hole cards, the first betting round begins with the player to the left of the big blind.The player can fold, call, or raise.Fold: Discard your hand and stop participating in the current hand.Call: Match the current bet (equal to the big blind if no raises have occurred).Raise: Increase the size of the current bet.This continues clockwise around the table until everyone has had a chance to act.

After the pre-flop round is complete, the dealer deals three community cards face-up in the center of the table. These cards are called the flop.A new round of betting begins with the player to the left of the dealer. This time, players can bet on the strength of their hand based on the community cards.Players can bet, check (if no one has bet), or raise.

After the flop, the dealer adds a fourth community card called the turn.Another round of betting takes place, again starting with the player to the left of the dealer.Players now have four community cards to use in combination with their hole cards to make their hand.
Finally, the dealer places the fifth and last community card called the river.The last betting round takes place, with the player to the left of the dealer once again beginning the betting.

After the final betting round (post-river), if there are two or more players left in the hand, the showdown occurs. Players reveal their hole cards, and the best five-card hand is determined by combining the hole cards and community cards.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand wins the pot. The hand rankings are the same as in traditional poker:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have the same hand, the kicker (the next highest card) is used to break the tie.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies for Texas Hold'em.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight: As a beginner, it's important to play fewer hands and only get involved with stronger starting hands. Good starting hands include pairs, high cards (Ace, King, Queen), and suited connectors (e.g., 10♠ J♠)..

Late position: Players who act later in the betting rounds have more information about what others are doing. This gives them an advantage. If you're in late position, you can make more informed decisions, including bluffing or playing weaker hands.
Don't be afraid to fold. If you don't have a strong hand and the community cards don't help you, it's better to fold than risk losing chips.

Bluffing is an essential part of Texas Hold'em, but it should be used carefully. As a beginner, you should only attempt bluffing when the situation makes sense. For example, bluff when you have a decent chance of winning with a weaker hand, or when the board favors a strong hand.
Learn to control the size of your bets. Betting too large can scare off opponents, while betting too small may not build a pot when you have a strong hand.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: A♠ K♥ (Ace of Spades and King of Hearts)
Blinds: The small blind posts 10 chips, and the big blind posts 20 chips.
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Player 2 (to your left) raises to 50 chips.

handWalkthroughParts.handWalkthroughPartsTitle: Flop (First three community cards are dealt)

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ + K♠ → Pair of Kings
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You bet 100 chips to build the pot.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Still: Pair of Kings (No improvement).
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You bet 200 chips, hoping to extract more value.

handWalkthroughParts.handWalkthroughPartsTitle: River (Fifth and final community card is dealt)

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Final Hand: Three of a Kind (Kings)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Player 2 bets 300 chips, representing a strong hand.
You consider for a moment and call the 300 chips.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal your three Kings, Player 2 reviels three nines, your three of a kind is stronger . You win the pot!

conclusion.conclusionInfo: You've now learned the basics of Texas Hold'em. This game is all about strategy, patience, and reading your opponents. Start practicing with friends or in online games, and don't worry if you lose a few hands early on—it's all part of the learning process.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Razz is to make the lowest possible five-card hand. Unlike traditional poker where you aim for the highest hand, in Razz, you want to have the lowest-ranked cards. Straights and flushes do not count against you, and aces are always low.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Razz is usually played with 2 to 8 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).
In Razz, there are antes, not blinds. All players must post an ante to start the hand. The ante amount can vary, but it's typically a small percentage of the pot.
The dealer button rotates clockwise after each hand, and the player to the left of the button posts the ante. In some variations, the dealer posts a small blind.

Hole Cards: Each player is dealt 7 cards, but only the first three are face down (known as 'hole cards'). The remaining cards are dealt face-up (called 'board cards') in subsequent rounds. Players can only see their own hole cards, and the face-up cards are visible to everyone.

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are 5 betting rounds in Razz. Here's how each one plays out:

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: The game begins with each player receiving 3 cards: two face-down hole cards and one face-up.The player with the highest card showing (determined by the value of the card, with Aces being high) is the first to act. This player is required to start with a forced bet (known as the 'bring-in' bet).Players can then fold, call, or raise based on their hand.

The dealer deals another face-up card to each player.The player with the best hand showing (the lowest hand based on the exposed cards) now starts the betting round.Players can again fold, call, or raise.
Another face-up card is dealt to each player.The player with the lowest face-up hand starts the betting round.
A final face-up card is dealt to each player.The betting proceeds the same way as the previous rounds, with the lowest hand acting first.
The final card is dealt face-down.A final round of betting takes place, with players checking, folding, calling, or raising based on their hand.

After the final round of betting, the remaining players reveal their seven cards. The player with the lowest hand (using five of the seven cards) wins the pot.Hand Rankings for Razz: In Razz, the lowest hand wins. The best hand is the lowest possible combination of five cards. Here's how the hand rankings break down:The Best Hand (A-2-3-4-5): This is the lowest possible hand in Razz and is called the “Wheel”.Other Low Hands: The next best hands are combinations like A-2-3-4-6, A-2-3-5-7, etc.Note that flushes and straights do not count against you in Razz.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand made up of any combination of the seven cards they've been dealt wins the pot. Here are some important things to remember:Straights and flushes don't matter in Razz—only the low value of the cards.Aces are always low, and the lowest hand wins.
howToWinParts: Five-High (A-2-3-4-5)
Six-High (A-2-3-4-6)
Seven-High (A-2-3-4-7)
Eight-High (A-2-3-4-8)
Nine-High (A-2-3-4-9)
Ten-High (A-2-3-4-10)
Jack-High (A-2-3-4-J)
Queen-High (A-2-3-4-Q)
King-High (A-2-3-4-K)
Pair (A-2-3-4-A, etc. — these hands are considered the weakest in Razz)
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have identical hands, the pot is split between them.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies for Razz

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight and avoid getting involved in hands with high cards like Kings or Queens, which will make it difficult to form a low hand.Good starting hands often include low cards like A-2-3, A-2-4, etc.

Acting later in the betting rounds gives you more information about your opponents' hands, so use this advantage to make better decisions.Don't Overestimate High Cards: Hands with high cards (8 or higher) are typically not strong in Razz. Focus on hands with lower cards.
Bluffing in Razz can be difficult since your cards are visible to others. Only bluff when you have a solid chance of winning, and avoid bluffing against players with strong low cards.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsTitle: Pay Attention to the Exposed Cards:
keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Since players cards are dealt face-up after the initial deal, keep track of the cards your opponents have. If they have a 7 and 8 showing, they are likely trying to make a low hand, so avoid playing against them with high cards.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Player 2 (to your left) raises to 30 chips.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: You now have a strong low hand: A-2-3-4-9.
Your Hand Now: A♠ 2♦ 3♠ 4♠ 5♠ (Best possible Razz hand - 'The Wheel')

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: Since player 2 folded the game ends before the Seventh Street and you win automaticlly because there is no other players left to compete with your hand

conclusion.conclusionInfo: Now that you've learned the basics of Razz, it's time to practice and improve your skills. Remember, patience and careful hand selection are key to succeeding in this unique poker variant.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: Note before you go into this variant, it is definitlly not for beginners so if you are totally new to poker we highly suggest you start with something like razz or texas hold'em, that said if you are up for a chellange go for it :).The goal of H.O.R.S.E. is to win the most chips by playing a series of five different poker games in one session. Each round of the game switches to a different poker variant, with each letter of H.O.R.S.E.' representing a different game. The games in H.O.R.S.E. are as follows:H - Hold'em (Texas Hold'em),O - Omaha,R - Razz,S - Seven Card Stud,E - Eight or Better (Hi-Lo Split)The player who wins the most chips across all five variants is the overall winner of the game.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: H.O.R.S.E. is usually played with 2 to 10 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).
Similar to Texas Hold'em, there are small and big blinds, and the player to the left of the dealer posts the small blind, while the next player posts the big blind.
The dealer button rotates clockwise after each hand to determine who deals and who posts the blinds.

Let's break down the five poker variants used in H.O.R.S.E.:H: Texas Hold'em This is the most familiar variant to most players. You receive two private hole cards, and five community cards are shared. Players make the best five-card hand using their hole cards and the community cards.O: OmahaIn Omaha, players receive four hole cards, but they must use exactly two of them in combination with three of the five community cards to form the best hand. This variant usually involves more action because players have more options to form a strong hand.R: RazzRazz is a lowball poker game where the goal is to make the lowest possible five-card hand. Straights and flushes do not count against you, and the ace is always low (A-2-3-4-5 is the best hand). In Razz, you are trying to avoid making high hands, so the best hand is a 5-4-3-2-A. S: Seven Card Stud In Seven Card Stud, there are no community cards. Each player is dealt seven cards, three face-down and four face-up. The best hand is made using five of these seven cards. Betting occurs after each round of cards is dealt.E: Eight or Better (Hi-Lo Split)In Eight or Better, also known as Omaha Hi-Lo or Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo, the pot is split between the highest and lowest hands. To qualify for the low half of the pot, a player's hand must contain five cards of 8 or lower. Straights and flushes do not count against you for the low hand, and the ace is considered low.

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: Each game in H.O.R.S.E. follows its own standard betting rules, but they share similar betting rounds: pre-flop, post-flop, and post-river (or equivalents depending on the variant).

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: Pre-flop: Players are dealt two hole cards. The small blind and big blind are posted. Players can fold, call, or raise.Post-flop: Three community cards are revealed. Another round of betting occurs.Post-turn: A fourth community card is dealt. Players bet again.Post-river: The fifth and final community card is dealt. The last round of betting takes place before the showdown.

Pre-flop: Players are dealt four hole cards. The blinds are posted. Players bet, fold, or raise.Post-flop: Three community cards are dealt.Post-turn: A fourth community card is dealt.Post-river: The final community card is dealt. The showdown occurs after the last betting round.

Pre-betting: Players are dealt two hole cards and one upcard. The player with the highest upcard must bring in (bet) to start the action.Post-third street: One more upcard is dealt, and another betting round occurs.Post-fourth, fifth, and sixth streets: Additional upcards are dealt with betting rounds following each.Showdown: After the final round, players reveal their hole cards, and the lowest hand wins.

Pre-betting: Players are dealt two hole cards and one upcard. The player with the lowest upcard must bet the bring-in.Post-third street: A second upcard is dealt, and a betting round occurs.Post-fourth, fifth, and sixth streets: Additional upcards are dealt with betting rounds in between.Showdown: After the seventh card is dealt, players reveal their hands, and the best five-card hand wins.

Pre-betting: Players are dealt two hole cards and one upcard, and the betting round begins with the player with the lowest upcard.Post-third street: Players are dealt additional upcards, with betting rounds in between.Post-fourth, fifth, and sixth streets: More upcards are dealt, and players continue betting.Showdown: After the seventh card is dealt, the pot is split between the highest hand and the lowest qualifying hand (if applicable).

howToWin.howToWinInfo: In H.O.R.S.E., the player with the most chips at the end of the five games wins. In each round, the rules of the variant being played apply, and players can win the pot according to the hand rankings for that variant.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies for H.O.R.S.E.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Texas Hold'em: Play tight with hands like pocket pairs, high cards (Ace, King), and suited connectors.Omaha: Focus on hands with high card potential and strong combinations, such as high pairs or suited connectors.Razz: Focus on getting low cards (A-2-3-4-5) and avoid high cards.Seven Card Stud: Start with strong starting hands, like a pair or suited connectors, and avoid starting with weak hands.Eight or Better: In Hi-Lo, you want to play both high and low hands. Keep an eye out for opportunities to scoop the pot with both the best high and low hands.
In all variants, players who act later in the betting rounds have more information and can make better decisions based on others' actions. Play more aggressively when you're in late position.

Adjust your bet size depending on the variant. In Seven Card Stud and Omaha, where the action can get big, it's important to control the size of the pot. In Razz, smaller bets may be more effective, as it's about avoiding the high hands.

Bluffing should be used cautiously, especially in games like Razz where players are trying to make the lowest hand. In games like Texas Hold'em and Omaha, bluffing is common, but in Seven Card Stud, it's less effective due to the number of visible cards.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Blinds:The small blind posts 10 chips, and the big blind posts 20 chips
Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ + K♠ → Pair of Kings
Your Hand Still: Pair of Kings (No improvement)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You check behind to see the next card for free.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ K♠ K♣ → Three of a Kind (Kings)
Your Final High Hand: Three of a Kind (Kings)
Your Final Low Hand: A-2-3-5-9 (Not a qualifying low hand, since it must be 8 or lower)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: No split occurs because no one qualifies for a low hand.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal three kings and win the pot

conclusion.conclusionInfo: H.O.R.S.E. is a great way to test your poker skills across multiple variants, each with its own set of challenges and strategies. By learning how to play all five games effectively, you can become a well-rounded poker player. Start practicing with friends or in online games to improve your understanding of these different poker types.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Pineapple is to make the best five-card hand using three hole cards and five community cards. The game is similar to Texas Hold'em, but with a twist: players are initially dealt three hole cards instead of two, and must discard one of them after the first betting round (pre-flop).

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Pineapple can be played with 2 to 10 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).

In Pineapple, there are two forced bets: the small blind and the big blind. These bets are made before the cards are even dealt and are designed to create action.Small Blind: The player to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually half of the big blind).Big Blind: The player two seats to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually the standard betting amount).These forced bets ensure that there's always something to play for, even before players start betting.

The dealer button rotates clockwise around the table after each hand. This determines which player is the dealer for that hand, as well as who posts the blinds. In casino play, the dealer is usually a non-playing staff member, but in home games, the button moves to each player.

In Pineapple, dealing happens pre-flop, meaning before any community cards are dealt.The dealer shuffles the deck and deals three hole cards face down to each player.Players can look at their own hole cards but should keep them hidden from others.The player to the left of the big blind starts the first betting round (pre-flop).

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are four betting rounds in Pineapple: Pre-flop, Post-flop, Post-turn, and Post-river. Let's break down each one.

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: After everyone receives their three hole cards, the first betting round begins with the player to the left of the big blind.The player can fold, call, or raise.Fold: Discard your hand and stop participating in the current hand.Call: Match the current bet (equal to the big blind if no raises have occurred).Raise: Increase the size of the current bet.This continues clockwise around the table until everyone has had a chance to act.

After the pre-flop round is complete, the dealer deals three community cards face-up in the center of the table. These cards are called the flop.A new round of betting begins with the player to the left of the dealer. This time, players can bet on the strength of their hand based on the community cards.Players can bet, check (if no one has bet), or raise.

After the flop, the dealer adds a fourth community card called the turn.Another round of betting takes place, again starting with the player to the left of the dealer.Players now have four community cards to use in combination with their hole cards to make their hand.
Finally, the dealer places the fifth and last community card called the river.The last betting round takes place, with the player to the left of the dealer once again beginning the betting.

After the final betting round (post-river), if there are two or more players left in the hand, the showdown occurs. Players reveal their hole cards, and the best five-card hand is determined by combining the hole cards and community cards.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand wins the pot. The hand rankings are the same as in traditional poker:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have the same hand, the kicker (the next highest card) is used to break the tie.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight: As a beginner, it's important to play fewer hands and only get involved with stronger starting hands. Good starting hands include pairs, high cards (Ace, King, Queen), and suited connectors (e.g., 10♠ J♠).

Late position: Players who act later in the betting rounds have more information about what others are doing. This gives them an advantage. If you're in late position, you can make more informed decisions, including bluffing or playing weaker hands.
Don't be afraid to fold. If you don't have a strong hand and the community cards don't help you, it's better to fold than risk losing chips.

Bluffing is an essential part of Pineapple, but it should be used carefully. As a beginner, you should only attempt bluffing when the situation makes sense. For example, bluff when you have a decent chance of winning with a weaker hand, or when the board favors a strong hand.
Learn to control the size of your bets. Betting too large can scare off opponents, while betting too small may not build a pot when you have a strong hand.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: A♠ K♥ Q♣ (Ace of Spades, King of Hearts, Queen of Clubs)
Blinds: The small blind posts 10 chips, and the big blind posts 20 chips.
Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ Q♣ + K♠ → Pair of Kings
Your Hand Still: Pair of Kings
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You check behind to see the next card for free.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ K♠ K♣ → Three of a Kind (Kings)

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal three kings and win the pot

conclusion.conclusionInfo: You've now learned the basics of Pineapple. This game adds an exciting twist to the standard Texas Hold'em rules by starting with three hole cards and forcing players to make strategic decisions about which card to discard. Start practicing with friends or in online games, and don't worry if you lose a few hands early on—it's all part of the learning process.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Omaha is to make the best five-card hand using exactly two of the four private hole cards dealt to you and three of the five community cards that are shared by all players. Omaha is similar to Texas Hold'em, but with more hole cards, which makes hand combinations more complex.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Omaha can be played with 2 to 10 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).

Like Texas Hold'em, Omaha uses two forced bets: the small blind and the big blind. These bets are made before the cards are even dealt and ensure there's always something to play for.Small Blind: The player to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually half of the big blind).Big Blind: The player two seats to the left of the dealer posts this bet (usually the standard betting amount).These forced bets ensure that there's always something to play for, even before players start betting.

The dealer button rotates clockwise around the table after each hand. This determines which player is the dealer for that hand, as well as who posts the blinds. In casino play, the dealer is usually a non-playing staff member, but in home games, the button moves to each player.

Dealing in Omaha happens pre-flop, meaning before any community cards are dealt. The dealer shuffles the deck and deals four hole cards face down to each player. Players can look at their own hole cards but should keep them hidden from others. The player to the left of the big blind starts the first betting round (pre-flop).

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are four betting rounds in Omaha: Pre-flop, Post-flop, Post-turn, and Post-river. Let's break down each one.

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: After everyone receives their four hole cards, the first betting round begins with the player to the left of the big blind.The player can fold, call, or raise.Fold: Discard your hand and stop participating in the current hand.Call: Match the current bet (equal to the big blind if no raises have occurred).Raise: Increase the size of the current bet.This continues clockwise around the table until everyone has had a chance to act.

After the pre-flop round is complete, the dealer deals three community cards face-up in the center of the table. These cards are called the flop.A new round of betting begins with the player to the left of the dealer. This time, players can bet on the strength of their hand based on the community cards. Players can bet, check (if no one has bet), or raise.

After the flop, the dealer adds a fourth community card called the turn. Another round of betting takes place, again starting with the player to the left of the dealer.Players now have four community cards to use in combination with their hole cards to make their hand.
Finally, the dealer places the fifth and last community card called the river. The last betting round takes place, with the player to the left of the dealer once again beginning the betting.

After the final betting round (post-river), if there are two or more players left in the hand, the showdown occurs. Players reveal their hole cards, and the best five-card hand is determined by combining exactly two hole cards with three community cards.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand wins the pot. The hand rankings are the same as in traditional poker:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have the same hand, the kicker (the next highest card) is used to break the tie.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight: As a beginner, it's important to play fewer hands and only get involved with stronger starting hands. Good starting hands include pairs, high cards (Ace, King, Queen), and suited connectors (e.g., 10♠ J♠). In Omaha, it's crucial to keep in mind that you must use exactly two of your hole cards.

Late position: Players who act later in the betting rounds have more information about what others are doing. This gives them an advantage. If you're in late position, you can make more informed decisions, including bluffing or playing weaker hands.
Don't be afraid to fold. If you don't have a strong hand and the community cards don't help you, it's better to fold than risk losing chips.

Bluffing is an essential part of Omaha, but it should be used carefully. As a beginner, you should only attempt bluffing when the situation makes sense. For example, bluff when you have a decent chance of winning with a weaker hand or when the board favors a strong hand.
Learn to control the size of your bets. Betting too large can scare off opponents, while betting too small may not build a pot when you have a strong hand.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: A♠ K♥ J♣ 10♠ (Ace of Spades, King of Hearts, Jack of Clubs, and 10 of Spades)
Blinds: The small blind posts 10 chips, and the big blind posts 20 chips.
Your Hand Now: A♠ K♥ J♣ 10♠ + Q♠ → Straight (5♠ 9♣ Q♠ K♥ J♣)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You raise to 250 chips, trying to build the pot.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Still: Straight (5♠ 9♣ Q♠ K♥ J♣)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You bet 300 chips, confident that your straight is still strong.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Final Hand: Straight (5♠ 9♣ Q♠ K♥ J♣)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You bet 500 chips, hoping to extract more value from your straight..

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal the straight and win the pot

conclusion.conclusionInfo: You've now learned the basics of Omaha. This game is all about strategy, patience, and reading your opponents. Start practicing with friends or in online games, and don't worry if you lose a few hands early on—it's all part of the learning process.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Seven Card Stud is to make the best five-card hand possible using a combination of your own hole cards and community cards. Unlike Texas Hold'em, Seven Card Stud doesn't use community cards that all players share. Instead, players each receive a combination of face-down and face-up cards over several betting rounds.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Seven Card Stud is typically played with 2 to 8 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).
Before the hand begins, all players are required to place an ante, a small bet that ensures there's money in the pot to play for.
The dealer is chosen randomly at the beginning of the game, and the dealer button rotates clockwise after each hand.

Dealing in Seven Card Stud happens in a series of steps, with a combination of face-down and face-up cards dealt to each player.Third Street (First Round of Cards) Each player is dealt two hole cards face down (private) and one up card (face-up). The player with the lowest up card must start the first round ofbetting.Fourth Street (Second Round of Cards) After the first betting round, each player receives one additional face-up card. Another round of betting takes place, starting with the playershowing the highest hand.Fifth Street (Third Round of Cards) Each player receives another face-up card. Another round of betting follows, again starting with the highest hand.Sixth Street (Fourth Round of Cards) Players receive one more face-up card, followed by another betting round.Seventh Street (Fifth and Final Round of Cards) The final card is dealt face-down to each player. After the last betting round, players reveal their hands and the best five-card handwins.

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are five total betting rounds in Seven Card Stud. Players can check, bet, raise, or fold depending on the strength of their hand and their

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: Each player is dealt two hole cards face-down and one face-up card. The player with the lowest face-up card must place a mandatory 'bring-in' bet. Betting proceeds clockwise, where players can fold, call, or raise.
Each remaining player receives a fourth card face-up. The player with the highest visible hand starts the betting. Players can check, bet, raise, or fold based on their hand's strength.
A fifth card is dealt face-up to each remaining player. The player with the strongest visible hand begins the betting round. Betting limits typically double at this stage.
Each player still in the hand receives a sixth card face-up. The highest visible hand starts the betting again. Players continue to check, bet, raise, or fold.

A final card is dealt face-down to each remaining player. The last round of betting takes place, starting with the player with the best visible hand. If multiple players remain, they reveal their hands, and the best five-card hand wins.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand wins the pot. The hand rankings are the same as in traditional poker:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have the same hand, the kicker (the next highest card) is used to break the tie.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: As a beginner, focus on playing strong hands like high pairs (e.g., Aces, Kings) and suited connectors (e.g., 10♠ J♠). Avoid starting with weaker hands unless they improve during the early rounds.

Since players reveal some cards face-up, you have the advantage of seeing what your opponents are holding. Take note of which cards are visible, as this can help you predict what other players might have..

While Seven Card Stud doesn't have the same position dynamics as Texas Hold'em (due to no community cards), betting last allows you to see what others have done before making your move. Use this information to make more informed decisions.
Don't be afraid to fold if your hand isn't improving, especially after the earlier betting rounds. If you're facing strong bets and don't have a solid hand, folding is often the best decision.

Bluffing can be a useful strategy in Seven Card Stud, but it requires careful timing. Bluffing works best when your opponents are showing weak hands or when you've managed to disguise the strength of your hand.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ (10 of Spades and 8 of Clubs)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Each player antes into the pot.
The player with the lowest up card posts the bring-in bet.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ 7♥ (The 7 of Hearts is dealt face-up)
Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ 7♥ 2♦ (The 2 of Diamonds is dealt face-up)
Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ 7♥ 2♦ 3♠ (The 3 of Spades is dealt face-up)

handWalkthroughParts.handWalkthroughPartsTitle: Seventh Street (Fifth and Final Round of Cards)

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ 7♥ 2♦ 3♠ (Your final hand remains unchanged)
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: The hand goes to the showdown.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand: 10♠ 8♣ 7♥ 2♦ 3♠  Your highest hand is a pair of tens.
Opponent's Hand: 4♦ K♠ 6♠ 5♣ 9♦  Your opponent wins with a straight (4♦ 5♣ 6♠ 7♥ 8♣).

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal the straight and win the pot

conclusion.conclusionInfo: You've now learned the basics of Seven Card Stud. This game requires attention to detail, careful hand selection, and reading your opponents. Start practicing with friends or online games, and don't worry if you lose a few hands early on—it's all part of the learning process.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Five Card Draw is simple: Make the best five-card hand using any combination of the five cards dealt to you. Unlike community card games, Five Card Draw has no shared community cards. The player with the best five-card hand (based on poker hand rankings) wins the pot.

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: Five Card Draw can be played with 2 to 6 players.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).

In Five Card Draw, there are no forced bets like blinds. Instead, players place an ante (a small bet to start the game) to create an initial pot. The ante ensures that there's always something to play for, even before the cards are dealt.
The dealer button rotates clockwise around the table after each hand. This determines which player deals the cards, but in casual play, everyone takes turns being the dealer.

In Five Card Draw, each player receives five cards dealt face down. Players can look at their own cards, but they should keep them hidden from others.The player to the left of the dealer posts the ante, and the dealer begins dealing five cards to each player.

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are two betting rounds in Five Card Draw: the pre-draw round and the post-draw round. Let's break them down.

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: After the cards are dealt, the first round of betting begins with the player to the left of the dealer. The player can choose to:Fold: Discard their hand and stop participating in the current hand.Call: Match the current bet (equal to the ante if no raises have occurred).Raise: Increase the size of the current bet.This continues clockwise around the table until everyone has had a chance to act.

After the pre-draw betting round, players can exchange any number of their cards for new ones. Each player can discard up to five cards and receive the same number of new cards from the deck. The player to the left of the dealer goes first, and the exchange continues clockwise around the table. Once all players have had a chance to draw new cards, a second round of betting begins.Post-Draw BettingAfter the draw, another round of betting takes place. The player to the left of the dealer starts the round. Players can choose to bet, check (if no one has bet), raise, or fold. The round continues until everyone has had a chance to act.

After the final betting round, if there are two or more players left in the hand, the showdown occurs. Players reveal their hole cards, and the best five-card hand is determined by each player's hand.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: The player with the best five-card hand wins the pot. The hand rankings are the same as in traditional poker:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: If two players have the same hand, the kicker (the next highest card) is used to break the tie.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight: As a beginner, it's important to play fewer hands and focus on stronger starting hands. Pairs, high cards (Ace, King), and suited connectors (e.g., 10♠ J♠) are good starting hands.Consider hand strength: Hands like Ace-King, pairs of Jacks, and suited cards are usually worth playing. However, avoid playing weak hands like low cards without strong potential.

Don't be afraid to fold: If your hand is weak, don't be afraid to fold, especially after the draw. In Five Card Draw, the chance to improve your hand is limited, so don't waste chips chasing unlikely combinations.

Bluffing is a part of poker, but it should be used carefully. As a beginner, you should only bluff when the situation makes sense, such as when you have a weak hand but the board shows no strong combinations for your opponents.

Learn to control the size of your bets. If you have a strong hand, consider betting enough to build the pot. If you have a weak hand, betting too much may scare your opponents into folding, preventing you from winning a bigger pot if you hit your draw.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Ante: Each player posts an ante of 10 chips.
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Player 1 (to your left) raises to 30 chips.
You call the 30 chips to see the draw.
The rest of the players fold.
handWalkthroughPartsInfo.handWalkthroughPartsInfoEndNote: Pot: 70 chips (your 30 + Player 1's 30 + 10 chips each in antes).

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: You decide to draw two new cards, discarding the 3♣ and 2♦.
The dealer gives you: J♠ Q♠.
Your Hand Now: 10♠ 10♦ J♠ Q♠ 8♠ (a Flush).

handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You bet 70 chips to try to extract value from your flush.
handWalkthroughPartsInfo.handWalkthroughPartsInfoEndNote: Pot: 210 chips (70 chips from each player).

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: You reveal your Flush (10♠ J♠ Q♠ 8♠) to Player 1, who reveals a Pair of Jacks.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You reveal the straight and win the pot

conclusion.conclusionInfo: You've now learned the basics of Five Card Draw. This game is all about hand strength and strategy, with fewer community cards to rely on compared to other poker games. Start practicing with friends or in online games to get a better feel for the game, and keep refining your strategy as you gain experience.

gameObjective.gameObjInfo: The goal of Omaha Hi/Lo 8 or Better is to make the best possible high hand and/or low hand using any combination of your four private hole cards and the five community cards. The best high hand wins half of the pot, and the best low hand wins the other half. To qualify for the low hand, the hand must consist of five cards of different ranks, all eight or lower (i.e., 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, Ace).

setup.setupInfo: Before we dive into gameplay, let's take a look at the setup

setupParts.setupPartsInfo: 2 to 10 players per game.
A standard 52-card deck is used (no jokers).

Similar to Texas Hold'em, the game uses forced bets called small blind and big blind.Dealer Button: The dealer button rotates clockwise after each hand. In a casino, the dealer is not a player, but in home games, it rotates among players.
The dealer button rotates clockwise after each hand. In a casino, the dealer is not a player, but in home games, it rotates among players.

Hole Cards: The dealer deals four hole cards face down to each player.Community Cards: The dealer places five community cards face up in the center of the table for all players to use in combination with their hole cards.

bettingRounds.bettingRoundsInfo: There are four betting rounds in Omaha Hi/Lo 8 or Better:

bettingRoundsParts.bettingRoundsPartsInfo: After all players receive their hole cards, the first round of betting begins with the player to the left of the big blind. Players can fold, call, or raise.
The dealer places the first three community cards face up (the flop). Another round of betting occurs, starting with the player to the left of the dealer.
A fourth community card (the turn) is dealt face up. Betting continues, starting with the player to the left of the dealer.
The fifth and final community card (the river) is dealt face up. The final betting round begins, with the player to the left of the dealer starting.

After the final betting round (post-river), if two or more players remain in the hand, the showdown occurs. Players reveal their hole cards, and the best high hand and low hand are determined.High Hand: The best five-card hand based on standard poker hand rankings.Low Hand: To qualify for a low hand, the player must have five cards with different ranks that are 8 or lower. The best low hand is the one with the lowest five cards, and Aces are considered low.

howToWin.howToWinInfo: High Hand: The player with the best five-card high hand wins half of the pot.Low Hand: The player with the best five-card low hand (with all ranks 8 or lower) wins the other half of the pot. If no player qualifies for a low hand, the entire pot is awarded to the player with the best high hand.Key Hand RankingsHere are the rankings for the high hand in Omaha Hi/Lo 8 or Better:
howToWinParts: Royal Flush  A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 10♠ (All same suit)
Straight Flush  5♣ 6♣ 7♣ 8♣ 9♣ (Five consecutive cards, same suit)
Four of a Kind  A♦ A♠ A♣ A♥ X (Four cards of the same rank)
Full House  Q♦ Q♠ Q♥ 4♠ 4♣ (Three of a kind + a pair)
Flush  Any five cards of the same suit (e.g., 2♦ 5♦ 7♦ J♦ K♦)
Straight  Five consecutive cards of any suit (e.g., 3♣ 4♦ 5♠ 6♥ 7♠)
Three of a Kind  9♠ 9♥ 9♣ X X (Three cards of the same rank)
Two Pair  J♠ J♣ 7♦ 7♣ X (Two pairs of the same rank)
One Pair  8♥ 8♣ X X X (Two cards of the same rank)
High Card  The highest card in hand if no other combination is made
Low Hand: A five-card hand with no cards ranked higher than 8. Aces count as low. For example, A♠ 2♦ 3♣ 4♥ 5♠ qualifies as a low hand.
howToWin.howToWinEndNote: Note: The '8 or better' rule means that if a player doesn't have five different cards ranked 8 or lower, they don't qualify for the low hand.

keyStrategies.keyStrategiesInfo: Now that you understand the flow of the game, let's talk about some beginner strategies.

keyStrategiesParts.keyStrategiesPartsInfo: Play tight and only play hands with potential for both high and low hands. Strong starting hands include hands with Aces, low connected cards, and suited cards.
As in all poker games, your position at the table is crucial. Players in late position have an advantage because they can see how the other players are betting before they make their move.
Not every hand will qualify for a low. It's important to aim for hands that can win both a high and low portion of the pot. Hands like A, 2, 3, 4, 5 are great for low hands.
Omaha Hi/Lo 8 or Better is unique in that the pot is split between the best high hand and best low hand. If no one qualifies for a low hand, the high hand wins the entire pot.
Try to control the size of the pot, especially when you only have a good low hand or a marginal high hand. It's essential to avoid overcommitting to the pot when you aren't in a strong position.
Bluffing can be an effective tool in Omaha Hi/Lo, but it should be used sparingly. Semi-bluffing, or betting when you have a strong draw for both high and low hands, can be an effective strategy.

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughInfo: Let's walk through an example hand to illustrate how the game flows.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Blinds: Small blind posts 10 chips, big blind posts 20 chips.
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: Player 1 (to your left) raises to 60 chips.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Now: A♠ 2♣ 7♦ 9♥ + 4♠ 6♣ → A♠ 2♣ 4♠ 6♣ 7♦ (You now have a straight and a low hand).
handWalkthroughPartsInfoList: You raise to 200 chips, hoping to build the pot for both a high and low win.

handWalkthroughPartsInfoPtag: Your Hand Now: A♠ 2♣ 4♠ 5♦ 6♣ → A♠ 2♣ 4♠ 5♦ 6♣ (You have a straight and a low hand).
Your Final Hand: A♠ 2♣ 4♠ 5♦ 6♣ (Low hand A-2-3-4-5) and a straight (4-5-6-7-8).

handWalkthrough.handWalkthroughEndNote: You win half the pot for the low hand (A♠ 2♣ 3♠ 4♠ 5♠), and if your straight is the best high hand, you win the other half.

conclusion.conclusionInfo: Omaha Hi/Lo 8 or Better is an exciting and strategic game that offers multiple ways to win the pot. By mastering starting hands, understanding when you can qualify for the low hand, and balancing high and low possibilities, you can significantly improve your chances of winning. Start practicing and learn when to fold, when to raise, and how to play both ends of the pot!
